comments.body: "from numeric import ..." already invokes "import numeric", that's how Python imports work. Does this actually make a difference, and if so, why?

There are some slightly unusual ways of importing that do not do this, usually by tools that are hooking into the import mechanism. Yaroslav found that ropemacs is one such tool. I have encountered it several times with nosetests depending on the directory where I start it.

Nonetheless, I can't believe that the answer is that we have to guard every "from ... import ..." just in case someone left out a basic language feature. There is tons and tons of code out there that depends on this working correctly. (Recently on the statsmodels list there was confusion abut whether circular imports were even possible, because they _never use_ the 'import ...' form.)

I'm not opposed to working around other people's bugs when necessary, but there has to be more to the story here.

I think you are misunderstanding the semantics of `from mod import ...`. It does _not_ do `import mod`. In most cases, doing `from mod import ...` will not put `mod` into the namespace.

```
[scratch]$ cat foo.py
from os import path
print os

[scratch]$ python foo.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "foo.py", line 2, in <module>
    print os
NameError: name 'os' is not defined
```

When `from mod import ...` is done inside of a package's `__init__.py` file and `mod` is a module inside that package, then `mod` gets inserted into the package's namespace as a _side effect_ of that module being imported. When modules inside of packages get imported (no matter where the import comes from), it gets inserted into the package's namespace, as long as no one is doing anything slightly weird. We wouldn't have to change any other instance of `from mod import ...` outside of `__init__.py` files. Certainly, no code outside of `__init__.py` files should be relying on `from mod import ...` to actually put `mod` in that namespace because it doesn't work that way.

But sometimes slightly weird things do happen. Code analysis tools will often want to import modules directly and thus miss some details like making sure that when executing the `__init__.py` code, it should be as a package and not just another module. Now it's fair to say that those tools should be fixed to be more robust, however, I think that it's also fair to explicitly import the names that we need instead of relying on a quirk of CPython's import implementation. I don't even know if it's documented well anywhere. It might not work exactly the same way on other implementations.

On Tue, May 22, 2012 at 12:18 PM, Robert Kern
reply@reply.github.com
wrote:

> I think you are misunderstanding the semantics of `from mod import ...`. It does _not_ do `import mod`. In most cases, doing `from mod import ...` will not put `mod` into the namespace.

Right, I know that :-). But I was misreading the bug report -- I
thought the claim was that "from numeric import *" was failing because
"numeric" had not yet been imported. In fact, like you say,
numpy/core/**init**.py is assuming that 'numeric' will appear in its
namespace when numeric gets imported. Which is confusing. Certainly it
confused me :-).

> it gets inserted into the package's namespace, as long as no one is doing anything slightly weird. We wouldn't have to change any other instance of `from mod import ...` outside of `__init__.py` files.

Yes, if that's the actual problem. See below.

> But sometimes slightly weird things do happen. Code analysis tools will often want to import modules directly and thus miss some details like making sure that when executing the `__init__.py` code, it should be as a package and not just another module. Now it's fair to say that those tools should be fixed to be more robust, however, I think that it's also fair to explicitly import the names that we need instead of relying on a quirk of CPython's import implementation. I don't even know if it's documented well anywhere. It might not work exactly the same way on other implementations.

The semantics of Python namespaces are pretty well nailed down; we
might well want to add explicit imports to make it less confusing, but
I wouldn't say that it's undocumented that the package and **init**
share a namespace.

Furthermore, it doesn't look like there's any hooking of the import
mechanism going on. AFAICT from the traceback, the sequence of events
is:

"pymacs.py" is a script that runs as a daemon for emacs to talk to.
Emacs starts up pymacs.py.

Emacs asks pymacs.py to do something like
eval("pyeval_load_helper('ropemacs', ...)")

pyeval_load_helper calls **import**("ropemacs"). Note that this is the
standard builtin **import** function, and AFAICT there are no import
hooks registered.

Then ropemacs imports difflib, and difflib does "from collections
import namedtuple". But, a sys.path screwup causes this to be hijacked
by another "collections.py" module in the working dir (maybe
matplotlib.collections? who knows). This interloper module then
imports numpy. So I suspect ropemacs has nothing to do with this -- it
hasn't made it past line 4 of ropemacs.**init** before the error
occurs. And even if numpy imported correctly, the code would still
crash, because this "collections.py" probably doesn't export
namedtuple.

OTOH, I tried doing eval("**import**('numpy')") in python 2.7, and it
worked fine. So I don't know why it doesn't work when pymacs calls
**import**.

I don't have any objection to adding import calls to make numpy's code
more explicit, but this seems to be a bug in either the Python
interpreter or perhaps pymacs, and should probably be filed
appropriately.

comments.body: It might be usefull someday to have a `format_message` function that would remove prefixed spaces so we could make these messages look better. IIRC @pv had, or knew of, a function that did that.
`textwrap.dedent` does that, I'm not aware of something fancier. but yes, may be useful especially for longer strings.

Importing the multiarray numpy extension module failed.  Most

comments.body: Possible enhancement - show as a bulleted list, and mark the entry that this print belongs to and the one multiarray belongs to.
The only use case for this message has been when pip/conda do not uninstall before installing, and reuse the same path. So as far as we know there will only ever be one item in `np.__path__`.
I thought there was another case where system-level installs were overriding user-level ones
I'll see if I can find it. I think `apt install python3-numpy` followed by `pip3 install numpy` causes it. Perhaps I'm mistaken.

comments.body: Is this behavior of returning strings documented anywhere? I don't see it in https://docs.python.org/3/library/pickle.html.

Its a bit confusingly documented in [`copyreg`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/copyreg.html#copyreg.pickle)

There is also a note on the [`__reduce__` doctsring](https://docs.python.org/3/library/pickle.html#object.__reduce__) (second paragraph)

I would be happy to just implement `__reduce__` as well though, I guess I felt this is a start on that route.

    return func.__name__

comments.body: PEP 8 wants two blank line between top level function definitions.
Fixed, had copied it from above, but rather changed it there (and moved the copyreg to be in one spot).

There was a subtlety/issue here. the change would have made `np.dtype` pickle in a way that older NumPy versions cannot unpickle. But when we pickle `np.dtype("f")` for example, we also pickle `np.dtype` to unpickle it.

That would have meant that any pickle containing a dtype instance (not class) would not have been unpickable on older NumPy versions.  For classes we cannot avoid that, but I am pretty sure that it would be inconvenient for the instances.

(EDIT: To be clear, in the initial version, I had `return None` and then special cased that in the reconstruct function.)
